title: Incredible moment bear approaches family hiking on Washington trail
text:
Wildlife officials say they did the right thing by standing still as running away could have encouraged the animal to chase after them

'I couldn’t even breathe. I was terrified, I didn't know what to do,' Jasmine said

Jason stood still and the bear lost interest and wandered off

The bear walked right up to her teenage brother Jason and sniffed him

They were 20 minutes into their hike near Myrtle Falls when what appeared to be a young black bear emerged from the wilderness

Jasmine Bartley was hiking with her family at Mount Rainier National Park in Washington on Sunday when a bear appeared and approached them on the trail

A family hiking through the Washington state mountains got the fright of their lives when a hungry bear roamed just inches away from them - and their decision to stand still may have saved them from getting attacked.

Jasmine Bartley and her family were hiking in Mount Rainier National Park on Sunday when a black bear suddenly appeared and walked right up to her teenage brother Jason.

Bartley says she knew something was wrong when she heard a woman gasp behind her, about 20 minutes into the hike near Myrtle Falls.

When she turned around she saw the young bear standing a few feet away from her brother as the rest of the group hiking with them frantically ran up the hill.

'I couldn’t even breathe. I was terrified,' Bartley said to KOMO. 'I didn’t know what to do. It was the first time seeing huge wildlife. And I was just scared. Gut-wrenching, honestly.'

Jasmine Bartley was hiking with her family at Mount Rainier National Park on Sunday when a bear appeared and approached them on the trail. The young bear stood just inches from her teenage brother Jason and sniffed him

Then the bear lost interest and scampered off the trail, however the beast did look back to give Jason one last look

The bear appeared to be on its own when it approached the group of hikers near Myrtle Falls

A person hiking with the group took video of the heart-stopping moment the bear appeared

A person hiking with the group took video of the heart-stopping moment the bear appeared and shows the young creature ramble through the grass and walk right up to Jason and inspect him for a moment.

A woman in the video is heard saying, 'Jason, don't move.'

The bear seems to get bored after a few moments and rambles off the the left. After taking a few steps away the bears look back at Jason and continues to scamper off the trail.

Bartley shared the clip on Facebook to educate others on the importance of being cautious while out in the wilderness.

She wrote: 'My little brother definitely had a close encounter in the park on Sunday!!'

'We’ve never seen a bear or knew what to do in the situation. We didn’t even see it until I said “wait, wait, wait,' she added.

The clip has gone viral racking up over 1,000 reactions.

The bear encounter took place at Mount Rainier National Park in Washington State (above)

'I had a lot of people educate me,' Bartley said. 'They immediately thought we were doing something wrong by trying to put ourselves in harms way, but we didn't even notice the bear. And there's other people who were just explaining how well we did and maybe to further protect ourselves - be more aware.'

Bartley says she loves the outdoors and will continue hiking and has since bought some bear spray.

Wildlife officials who have seen the video say the encounter is rather unusual.

'I can’t say I’ve ever seen a video of that happening in that type of location before,' Capt. Jeff Wickersham with Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife Police.

He added that the family did the right thing in not running away and standing still.

'They didn’t try to approach the animal. When the bear walked up to the one hiker and got right at their feet, there’s not much you can do at that range and that proximity. You know, in that circumstance – you could have done many things. But I don’t think they did anything wrong,' he said.

He advised that when confronted by a bear in the wild, hikers should try to make themselves appear bigger than they are.
